column4: hi all i have questions concerning the use of UUID in ubuntu for fstab
this UUID is different for any  distro i install on my computer, so I think this UUID have nothing universal
and that /dev/sd* was MUCH more universal than this UUID system
so I wonder why ubuntu use this false universal identifier ?
i think it's unique to the system/bus/disk
so if I have 2 ubuntu on my diskm i cant chroot from 1 ubuntu to the other cause they have different UUID ?
this UUID system in fstab will create much more problems than it is useful
i don't think that would make any difference, /etc/fstab isn't used during a chroot afaik

the whole point is that you can move disks around and such and it'll always use the correct drive for that install, rather than using the /dev/sd* which change depending on where the disk is plugged in/configured
installing 2 ubuntu on the same disk will give 2 different UUID for the SAME partition !
and breaks many things that were working before, like chrooting fron one ubuntu instance to another
it works pretty well actually.  if you'd rather, you can replace UUID= with LABEL= and use the volume label
i don't think /etc/fstab is parsed during a chroot, unless you mount -a i suppose
there are thousands of people having problems wit this _not_ _universal_ UUID system
I just wanted to say this
I ll fond workarounds , but the best workaround will be to find a distro not using the UUID system in fstab . . .
what exactly is your problem?  it's universally unique on your system, and allows you to shuffle around drives without having to touch /etc/fstab.  it's really a nice feature
